facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 124 to 129 of 1964 were filed in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeals Nos. 124 to 129 of 1964.

facts.text: Appeals from judgment and decree dated March 23, 1961 of Allahabad High Court.

anchor.surface_text: Appeals from the judgment and decree dated March 23, 1961 of the Allahabad High Court in Civil Misc.

facts.text: Allahabad High Court heard Civil Misc. Writs Nos. 2127, 2128 and 2980 to 2983 of 1959.
Appellants are Hindu undivided families charged under section 3 of Wealth-Tax Act, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: The respective appellants in these appeals who constitute Hindu undivided families were charged under s. 3 and they challenged

facts.text: Appellants challenged validity of section 3 Wealth-Tax Act as ultra vires.

anchor.surface_text: charged under s. 3 and they challenged the validity of the said charge on the ground that the said section was ultra vires.

facts.text: Writ petitions heard by Special Bench of Allahabad High Court: Gurtu, Upadhya, and Jagdish Sahai JJ.

anchor.surface_text: The writ petitions filed by these appellants were heard by a Special Bench of the Allahabad High Court consisting of Gurtu, Upadhya,

facts.text: Gurtu and Jagdish Sahai JJ rejected appellants' contention and upheld validity of section 3.

anchor.surface_text: Gurtu and Jagdish Sahai, JJ. have rejected the appellants' contention and have upheld the validity of the impugned provision.

facts.text: Jagdish Sahai J held section intra vires under Entry 86 List 1.

anchor.surface_text: According to Jagdish Sahai, J., the impugned section is intra vires, because Parliament had legislative competence to enact

facts.text: Gurtu J upheld under Entry 97 List 1 read with Article 248.

anchor.surface_text: Gurtu, J. who agreed with the said conclusion, however sustained the impugned provision under Entry 97 in List 1 read with Art.

facts.text: Upadhya J held section ultra vires, no competence under Entries 86 or 97.

anchor.surface_text: Upadhya, J. held that neither of the said provisions conferred legislative competence on Parliament to enact the impugned provision,

facts.text: Writ petitions dismissed by majority decision of Allahabad High Court.

anchor.surface_text: In accordance with the majority decision, the writ petitions filed by the respective appellants were dismissed.

facts.text: Appellants obtained certificates from High Court and appealed to Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants then applied for and obtained certificates from the said High Court, and it is with the certificates issued

facts.text: Wealth-Tax Act, 1957 (No. 27 of 1957) passed to levy wealth tax.

anchor.surface_text: The Act was passed in 1957 to provide for the levy of wealth tax.

facts.text: Section 3 charges wealth-tax for every financial year commencing on and from April 1, 1957 on net wealth of individual, HUF, company.

anchor.surface_text: Section 3 of the Act provides that subject to the other provisions contained in this Act, there shall be charged for every financial year commencing on and from the first day of April, 1957,

facts.text: Appellants contend 'individuals' in Entry 86 does not include Hindu undivided families.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants contend that the word individuals used in Entry 86 cannot take in Hindu undivided families.

facts.text: Respondent contends 'individuals' in Entry 86 includes Hindu undivided families.

anchor.surface_text: It is contended on his behalf that the word individuals used in Entry 86 is wide enough to take within its sweep groups of individuals

facts.text: Supreme Court held section 3 valid as Parliament competent under Entry 86 for HUFs.

anchor.surface_text: We are, therefore, satisfied that the impugned section is valid, because Parliament was competent to legislate in respect of Hindu undivided families under Entry 86.

facts.text: Several High Courts upheld validity under Entry 86: Bombay, AP, Mysore, Madras.

anchor.surface_text: This question has been considered by several High Courts and the reported decisions show consensus in judicial opinion in favour of the construction of Entry 86 which we have adopted vide Mahavirprasad Badridas v.

facts.text: Judgment delivered by Gajendragadkar, C.J.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by Gajendragadkar, C. J.

facts.text: Common question: validity of section 3 Wealth-Tax Act levy on net wealth of Hindu undivided family.

anchor.surface_text: The common question of law which this group of six appeals raises for our decision is whether section 3 of the Wealth-Tax Act, 1957

section 3 of the Wealth-Tax Act, 1957 (No. 27 of 1957) hereinafter called the Act in so far as it purports to levy a charge of wealth tax in respect of the net wealth of a Hindu undivided family at the specified rate, is valid.

concepts.interpretation: Court upholds validity of levy on net wealth of Hindu undivided families as within Parliament's competence under Entry 86.

issues.text: whether section 3 of the Wealth-Tax Act, 1957 (No. 27 of 1957) hereinafter called the Act in so far as it purports to levy a charge of wealth tax in respect of the net wealth of a Hindu undivided family at the specified rate, is valid

anchor.surface_text: section 3 of the Wealth-Tax Act, 1957 (No. 27 of 1957) hereinafter called the Act in so far as it purports to levy a charge of wealth tax in respect of the net wealth of a Hindu undivided family at the specified rate, is valid.

issues.text: whether the impugned provision can be referred to Entry 86

anchor.surface_text: Entry 86 in List 1 deals with taxes on the capital value of the assets, exclusive of agricultural land, of individuals and companypanies taxes on the capital of companypanies.

issues.text: whether the word individuals used in Entry 86 cannot take in Hindu undivided families

anchor.surface_text: The appellants contend that the word individuals used in Entry 86 cannot take in Hindu undivided families.

issues.text: whether Entry 97 in List 1 read with Art. 248 sustains the impugned provision

anchor.surface_text: Entry 97 in the said List refers to any other matter number enumerated in List II or List III including any tax number mentioned in either of those Lists. Article 248 reads thus - Parliament has exclusive power to make any law with respect to any matter number enumerated in the Concurrent List or State List.

issues.text: whether Entry 82 contrasted with Entry 86 imports limitation on individuals

anchor.surface_text: Entry 82 refers to taxes on income other than agricultural income. The argument is that the power to levy taxes on income is not conditioned by reference to individuals or companies.

issues.text: whether legislative history of income-tax acts limits construction of individuals in Entry 86

issues.text: whether the word individuals in Entry 86 includes groups of individuals like Hindu undivided families

anchor.surface_text: In construing the word individuals used in the said Entry, it is necessary to remember that the relevant words used in the Entries of the Seventh Schedule must receive the widest interpretation.

arguments.claim: The word 'individuals' used in Entry 86 cannot take in Hindu undivided families as they are groups of individuals

anchor.surface_text: The appellants contend that the word individuals used in Entry 86 cannot take in Hindu undivided families. The taxes which Parliament is empowered to levy under this Entry can be levied only on individuals and not on groups of individuals, and on companies.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: that the word individuals in the companytext cannot mean companypanies, because companypanies are separately and distinctly mentioned that again, it

arguments.court_reasoning: Words in entries must receive widest interpretation; individuals includes groups forming a unit like HUFs.

arguments.claim: Taxes under Entry 86 can only be levied on individuals and companies, not on groups of individuals like HUFs

anchor.surface_text: A Hindu undivided family consists of different coparceners who are, no doubt, individuals, but inasmuch as the impugned provision purports to levy wealth tax on the capital value of the assets of the Hindu undivided families as such, the tax is not levied on individuals, but on groups of individuals, and, therefore, is outside the scope of Entry 86.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: levied on capital gains was impeached on the ground that capital gains cannot be regarded as income, and so, Entry 54 did number justify the levy of

arguments.court_reasoning: Individuals wide enough to include groups owning assets jointly; aggregation of shares is legislative matter.

arguments.claim: If HUFs outside Entry 86, then cannot be under Entry 97 as wealth tax specifically in Entry 86

anchor.surface_text: The appellants further urge that if the Hindu undivided families are outside the scope of Entry 86, they cannot be subjected to the levy of wealth tax under Entry 97, because Entry 97 refers to matters other than those specified in Entries 1 to 96 in List 1 as well as those enumerated in Lists II and III.

arguments.claim: Article 248 must be read with Entry 97; if outside 86 and 97, no competence under 248

anchor.surface_text: In regard to Art. 248, the appellants argument is that the said article must be read together with Entry 97 in List 1. and if wealth tax in respect of the capital value of the assets of Hindu undivided families is outside both Entry 86 and Entry 97, the residuary power of legislation conferred on Parliament by Art. 248 cannot be invoked

arguments.claim: Contrast with Entry 82 shows Entry 86 limited to individuals and companies

anchor.surface_text: The appellants no doubt contrast Entry 86 with Entry 82 and contend that the said contrast brings out an element of limitation or restriction which should be imported in construing Entry 86. Entry 82 refers to taxes on income other than agricultural income.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: their shares in the capital assets of their respective families are liable to increase or decrease and cannot be definitely predicated for the account

arguments.court_reasoning: No reasonable to import limitation by contrasting entries; interpret naturally and widely.

arguments.claim: Individuals cannot include companies as companies separately mentioned, so excludes groups

arguments.court_reasoning: Companies specified as precaution; individuals still wide to include groups.

arguments.claim: Word individuals in Entry 86 wide enough to include groups like HUFs

anchor.surface_text: It is contended on his behalf that the word individuals used in Entry 86 is wide enough to take within its sweep groups of individuals and as such, Hindu undivided families fall within the scope of the area covered by Entry 86.

arguments.claim: Article 248 confers residuary power independently of lists

anchor.surface_text: In regard to Art. 248, the respondents case is that this article prescribes the residuary power of legislation conferred on Parliament and must be read independently of the Lists.

arguments.claim: Entries in Seventh Schedule must receive widest interpretation

anchor.surface_text: In construing the word individuals used in the said Entry, it is necessary to remember that the relevant words used in the Entries of the Seventh Schedule must receive the widest interpretation.

arguments.claim: No limitation by contrasting Entry 86 with Entry 82

anchor.surface_text: We are not impressed by this argument. It is true that Entry 82 does not refer to the assessees, ... Since Entry 86 refers to taxes on the capital value of the assets, the Constitution-makers must have thought that it was necessary to specify whose assets should be subject to the taxes contemplated by the Entry

arguments.claim: Plural 'individuals' includes singular/groups per General Clauses Act s13

anchor.surface_text: The use of the word individuals in the plural is not of any special significance, because under S. 13 (2) of the General Clauses Act, 1897 (No. 10 of 1897 ), words in the singular shall include the plural, and vice versa.

arguments.claim: Irrational to exclude HUFs from wealth tax; policy

anchor.surface_text: The basic assumption on which the appellants argument rests is that the Constitution-makers wanted to exclude the capital value of the assets of Hindu undivided families from taxes. ... On the face of it, -it is impossible to assume that while thinking of levying taxes on the capital value of assets, Hindu undivided families could possibly have been intended to be left out.

arguments.claim: Legislative history does not limit constitutional interpretation

anchor.surface_text: Assuming that the legislative history ... supports the distinction ... we do not see how the said consideration can have a material bearing on the construction of the word individuals in Entry 86.

arguments.claim: 'Individual' includes group forming unit (Sodra Devi precedent)

anchor.surface_text: In Commissioner of Income-tax, Madhya Pradesh Bhopal v. Sodra Devi ... the word individual ... is wide enough to include a group of persons forming a unit.

arguments.claim: High Courts consensus upholds under Entry 86

anchor.surface_text: This question has been considered by several High Courts and the reported decisions show consensus in judicial opinion in favour of the construction of Entry 86 which we have adopted vide Mahavirprasad Badridas v.

holdings.text: The impugned section 3 of the Wealth-Tax Act, 1957 is valid as it levies wealth tax on the net wealth of Hindu undivided families.

anchor.surface_text: section 3 of the Wealth-Tax Act, 1957 (No. 27 of 1957) hereinafter called the Act in so far as it purports to levy a charge of wealth tax in respect of the net wealth of a Hindu undivided family at the specified rate, is valid.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Parliament competent under Entry 86 as 'individuals' includes Hindu undivided families; widest interpretation of entries; rejection of contrary arguments; High Court consensus.

holdings.text: The impugned provision falls within Entry 86 of List I of the Seventh Schedule.

anchor.surface_text: Entry 86 in List 1 deals with taxes on the capital value of the assets, exclusive of agricultural land, of individuals and companies taxes on the capital of companies.

holdings.reasoning_summary: 'Individuals' wide enough to include groups like HUFs owning assets jointly; no narrow construction; follows High Courts.

holdings.text: The word 'individuals' in Entry 86 includes Hindu undivided families as groups of individuals.

anchor.surface_text: In construing the word individuals used in the said Entry, it is necessary to remember that the relevant words used in the Entries of the Seventh Schedule must receive the widest interpretation.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Widest interpretation of constitutional entries; includes groups forming unit per Sodra Devi; General Clauses Act s.13; policy against exclusion; legislative history irrelevant.

holdings.text: Word 'individuals' in Entry 86 cannot be limited by contrast with Entry 82.

anchor.surface_text: We are not impressed by this argument. It is true that Entry 82 does not refer to the assessees, ... Since Entry 86 refers to taxes on the capital value of the assets, the Constitution-makers must have thought that it was necessary to specify whose assets should be subject to the taxes contemplated by the Entry

holdings.reasoning_summary: No reasonable basis to import limitation by comparing entries; interpret naturally without restriction.

holdings.text: Legislative history of income-tax acts does not limit construction of 'individuals' in Entry 86.

anchor.surface_text: Assuming that the legislative history ... supports the distinction ... we do not see how the said consideration can have a material bearing on the construction of the word individuals in Entry 86.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Constitutional terms not restricted by statutory practice; cites Navinchandra and Navnitlal precedents.

holdings.text: Parliament was competent to legislate in respect of Hindu undivided families under Entry 86.

anchor.surface_text: We are, therefore, satisfied that the impugned section is valid, because Parliament was competent to legislate in respect of Hindu undivided families under Entry 86.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct conclusion from wide interpretation of 'individuals'; covers HUFs; no need for Entry 97 or Art. 248.

holdings.text: The construction of Entry 86 upheld by several High Courts is approved.

anchor.surface_text: This question has been considered by several High Courts and the reported decisions show consensus in judicial opinion in favour of the construction of Entry 86 which we have adopted vide Mahavirprasad Badridas v.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Consensus supports inclusion of HUFs under Entry 86; lists Bombay, AP, Mysore, Madras decisions.

holdings.text: Impugned provision valid under Entry 86 itself; no need to consider Entry 97 or Art. 248.

anchor.surface_text: Since we have come to the conclusion that Entry 86 covers cases of Hindu undivided families, it follows that the impugned provision is valid under the said Entry itself.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Primary ground sufficient; residuary not reached.
